replies.comment info:
Hi, @Brianna C --

The assumptions used in this graph (we listed them in the release’s instructions) came from data from around the world.  To learn more about the data and its effect on the graphs, go to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) 23-minute video (https://tinyurl.com/3BrBlSim).  It shows simulations of the effect of more variables, including identifying and isolating infected people, degree of social distancing, travel restrictions, changing the contagious rate, and addressing “hot spots.”  They post five key takeaways that frame the possible courses of Covid-19 that could be a basis of discussion.
As the statistician George Box said, “All models are wrong.  Just some are useful.” But, at this point, the models are our best guess of the effects of different interventions on a coronavirus that is called “novel.”  As we collect more data from around the world, we will be able to improve our models and better predict what could happen.

name: Moderator
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  
Today’s graphs, that appeared elsewhere in NYTimes.com, show a model of how interventions like social distancing, school and business closings, hospital support and diagnostic testing might impact the spread of Covid-19.
The graphs are from a U.S. simulation model for Jan. through Oct. They use these assumptions: length of intervention varies (7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42 days as shown on graphs), intervention starts on March 26, intervention level is aggressive, weather is medium warm, infected people transmit the virus to 2.5 other people, hospitalization rate is 10 percent, and death rate is 1 percent. Other assumptions include incubation, infectious and recovery period, time to death, and delay to visit hospital.
If you click on "email me when my comment is published." you will get a link to your response.  You can share this with others who want to see your response or reply to it.
By Friday, we’ll reveal the article that included these graphs, the interactive version and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
The next graph will be released Fri., Apr. 17 with moderation on Wed., Apr. 22.  The graph is about our spending habits.  What did you used to buy?  What do you buy now?  Stay tuned.

name: Lily
comment info:
I noticed that the graphs show the changes in the number of people infected, hospitalized and killed by the virus. Each graph increases from top left to top right in the number of days of interventions each time by 7 days. The x-axis represents the months (January, April, July and October, increasing by 3 months); the y-axis represents the number of people (10 million, 20 million and 30 million, increasing by 10 million). The shaded gray area represents the number of days of intervention. The light red shade is the people infected; the medium red shade is the people hospitalized; the dark red shade is the number of people deceased.

comment info: I notice that the more "interventions" that people follow the more that the infection, hospitalization, and deceased rates flatten out. For every week that people stay indoors and practice social distancing, the faster we will be able to resume our regular lifestyle. I wonder what percentage of the population must practice these interventions in order for these graphs to become reality. This graph shows us how important following the "stay at home" order and other interventions is and how it can affect the spread of the virus significantly. I would title this graph "Stay at Home and Slow the Spread!"

name: No_1_of_importance
comment info: I notice that on this graph it shows the number of infected (the sidebar on the left) in millions of people. Additionally, the higher the number of days of interventions, the more the number of hospitalized, infected, and deceased flat-lines, or flattens out. I'm curious about how long it will take interventions to eliminate the increasing number of infected, hospitalized, and deceased patients. A cool name for the graph would be "Analytics on the Proof of Interventions", if I used any of those words properly.

replies.comment info:
HI, @No_1_of_importance --

Please return late tomorrow after when we will release the link to the original article that included these graphs.  The article also has another interactive graph toward the end of the article that allows you to change seven variables -- intervention length, start and level; warm weather effect; infectiousness level; and hospitalization and death rates.  It then shows you the resulting graph and the number of  infected and deceased persons.  In an organized way, try combinations of values, collect statistics, and reflect on what you know now about Covid-19 and what we should do to reduce its effect.

name: Victoria Payne
comment info:
I noticed that the longer that the intervention period time is in the graph, less and less people are infected, hospitalized, and die. You can see this because the peaks go down in all of the graphs while still having the same scale on the y-axis. When you look at the graphs you can also see that when you go from twenty-one days to twenty-eight the peaks of each shade of red go down about fifty percent. This continues to happen for the remainder of the graphs which can show exponential decay in the number of cases if people start to intervene and take all of the precautions necessary.
I wonder if we were to go another twenty-one days after the forty-two shown, if people could start going back to life as usual or if it could happen before that? Life might not be like it used to be before this pandemic, but even if we could start having contact with people in very few amounts without having to social distance ourselves it would be a start on the road to recovery.
Catchy Headline: Stay Inside and Things Will Subside!
